text:
Hello and welcome
to This is My Architecture.

Today, it is my pleasure
to welcome Enoptea.
Hello Gaultier.
Hello.
You're Enoptea's CTO.

Can you tell us a little bit more
about your business?
At Enoptea, we are software publishers
and we edit a SaaS platform for analyzing
consumption data and energy billing

for customers with highly multi-site
operations.

All right, do you have
some figures in relation to that?
Today, it's about a hundred customers

who are using 12,000 electricity
and gas consumption sites.
That's about 300,000 bills

and 30 million finished
consumption points.
All right.
Today, you will show us the architecture
of your back-end.

Can you tell me a little bit
about the role of this application?

The role of this application
is to retrieve invoices,
digitize them, analyze the data

and generate reports
that detect various elements:

billing errors,
contract optimizations, etc.
All right.
Well, let's go into a little bit of detail.

Can you walk us
through this architecture
so that we understand?

We have the front end,
which is rather on very classic services,

with a load balancer that uses
Elastic Beanstalk and therefore EC2.
From these services, we read directly

into our databases in order
to display data,
compute listings, etc.

And this is the part that is
accessible to our customers.

Then, we have all the back-end
data processing part,
which has an originality,

which is that it runs serverless
with the PHP language.

So, we have several dozen services
running particularly in Lambda,
and using heavily AWS internal events.
The first service will retrieve
invoices from suppliers' customer areas.

Then, these invoices
are deposited in an S3 bucket.

And there, AWS internal events
are triggered
and will fill one or more SQS queues,

which will trigger one or more Lambdas
to do different processing.
All right.
The data is then stored
either in our standard databases
or in Cache databases
because it's more or less temporary data.
All right.

I understand that we can also
trigger processing from the front.
Yes, absolutely.

Well, this is the analysis
of our synthesis generation.
Data will go through an API Gateway

that will trigger different Lambdas
and create Caches.
All right.

I think you said Lambdas
were developed in PHP.
Yes, they were.
How did you manage that?

So, yes, it's true
that originally, it's not
a supported language on AWS Lambda.

The idea, at first, was to use
an open source project called Bref,

which allows, with use
of a small Node.js hack,

to use the PHP executable
that is included in our Lambda.
This is the version that was implemented
about a year, a year and a half ago.

And since then, thanks
to the new version of Lambda

which is a bit more up to date,
we use Custom Runtime and Layers.

As the layer is embedding
a real PHP executable,

we achieve a little more native
performances of the language.
All right, ok.

So, you embed a layer,
you've created a layer

that embed the PHP runtime,
that you use on all your Lambda.
Exactly.
All right.

In terms of deployment,
how does that work?
Well, today, most of our services,

about more than 10 services,
run entirely in serverless mode.

Thus, in order to allow for a more flexible
and efficient deployment,
we do a lot of continuous deployment.
And just for the record,
we had to ask very, very quickly

for an increase in the limit
of the Lambda service
since we have highly parallel processing,
the idea being that for each site,
we recover two or three years of history.

So, that's about several
dozen invoices for each site,

and since our clients have
several thousand sites,
it can increase quickly.

Today we are at the limit
of 10,000, in terms of Lambda

and network interfaces,
in a single region.

All right, so we understand
why you used Lambda.
It's especially for scalability.
Thatâ€™s it.

But you've got up
to just under 10,000 Lambda's
running in parallel sometimes.
Exactly.
All right.
All right.
Is there any other reason why
you used serverless technology?
Well, the reason is rather a human one.
We're a small team even now
and we don't have DevOps or Sysadmin.
Also, it's true that developers,

the less they worry about infrastructure,
the better off they are.
So that's the choice we made.

And then, the second choice,
it is more in the logic of the execution

which is highly event-driven
and therefore fits well with this model.
All right.
In terms of future developments,
I believe that the front will evolve.
That's right, exactly.
The idea is that we could imagine
doing away with slightly classic services

and pushing the serverless logic
with an entry point
that would become an API Gateway

and that would allow us to call
our different Lambdas directly.
All right.

The idea is also that,
when we switch to serverless,

we'd be able to scale
the storage systems behind it

and thus potentially switch from RDS
to Aurora, or even Aurora Serverless.

Yes,  in order to increase
and have better performance

on the serverless side.
For the same reason you would be using Lambda to increase performance.
Exactly.
All right.

Well, Gaultier, thank you for sharing
this architecture with us.
Thanks to you.

And see you soon for another episode
of This is My Architecture.
